These are troubled times. There is no academic

world. Never before has man been so buffeted by the

Your freshman, and every one else it seems to us,
should paste in his hat, before all other bits of advice,
the late Justice Holmes' definition of the old-fashioned
liberal.
A Holmes liberal, you may remember, is one who
simply cannot believe himself to be God.

It seems that these are revolutionary times. Elsewhere
in this issue can be found a
full account of the recent
changes which have been instituted in the conduct of
University life, changes so
profound that their import can hardly be realized
at this time. Most of the changes seem long overdue,
but their final effect must abide the question.
So far as the new dance program is concerned, there
seems to be little purpose in looking back. The sins
of the Cotillion Board should be forgotten as soon as
possible. The main business at hand is the future of the
de-emphasis plan. It can only succeed with the spirited
cooperation of the student body. Without such support,
we can anticipate only a return to the old order. And
we submit, there is no place on a progressive campus
for an organization like the Cotillion Board.
We are frankly disappointed with the passing of the
Blue Jay. It is hard to keep down a certain regret for
what might have been. The Jay in its old, half-caste
state may have been a pretty feeble affair. But, on potentialities alone, it deservd a better fate.
There are certain aspects of the purge which may
seem a bit unfortunate. For example, it is another
example of the ancient Council custom of presenting its
decisions to the campus as faits accomplis. Under the
circumstances, no other method offered itself. But
the Council should proceed as quickly as possible to
eradicate any traces of discontent by giving the widest
advance publicity to its future.
Most of the current talk about Council dictatorship
has come from persons who have been hardly conspicious for faith in democracy in the past. But the

In the long run, we suspect that the best Council is

The best government is not always the least government. It is rather that government which combines

a constant sensitiveness to their wishes. And, that seems
is the general direction in which the Council is moving.
